My trembling soul: it dares not leave my breast,
Mount to the flaming girdle of the world,
And fetch me lightnings, I will swallow it.
Snatch from the Cyclops balls of Etnean fire
And I will eat them: steal thunder from the clouds
And dart it at me: quaff Stygian Nonocris
I will pledge thee.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: I'll haunt thee to despair. Exit Borgias. Timoclea following him▪

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.l: Pursue his fear to some effect of death,
Whilst I like stars that spread their sparkling fires
Beyond an usual light foreshow a tempest
Of the whole state of Florence. Amadas removed
Her near alliance unto Julia's blood,
Shall not distaste my hopes: Timocleas' fear
Works death on Borgias: up mulleasses
Sit like Saturnus on the highest orb,
and let stargazing wizards from thy fear,
Buzz sad astrology in the people's ear.

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: What night or what dark chaos can conceal
My conscience horror? rather let me see
The fear of Hercules: let the Cretian bull
Bellow and burst my brains: only may my ears
Be deaf to thy exclaims.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: Thou art at farthest.

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: Then I can but fall. He leaps down.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: Like Lucifer from heaven.Discendit Timoclea.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.l: O now methinks a chorus all of angels
Clad with the sun and crowned with golden stars,
Should make more heavenly music at thy fall
Then all the spheres that dance about the ball:
Now should they poetize in verse for joy,
And outsing Homer in the fall of Troy.

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: Villain triumphest thou?

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.l: O ye strong power of superstitious faith
It reigns on fools: that men of wit and state,
Men that like eagles climb to be above,
And shroud themselves between the knees of Jove
Should be struck down by apparitions.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: Delusive counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: Conterfeit!

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: I Valentine I live▪
And am the actor of mine own revenge.
That cup of poison made against my life,
Was by my dearest mulleasses love
Turned to a philtre: and my working sense,
Charmed in the silence of a quiet sleep,
showed as if death had locked my pulses up,
But posting time brought motion on my blood.
And now my full veins like a water-brook,
That sliding gently at some proud hills foot,
In pipes of lead are carried to the top,
And there in amorous branches spreading forth,
Courts the curled mountain thus, thus, and thus:She kisses him.

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: Lascivious strumpet.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: My beloved Turk.

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: Incestuous Phedra.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: Love Hippolytus.

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: Cruel Medea.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: My kind Jason.

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: Whirl me ye just and more auspicious powers,
Amongst the thick and thunder darting clouds,
That being wrapped in flames I may be thrown,
Like Aetnean balls from heaven and strike you down:
Or would my dying breath were more infectious
Than half rotten bodies digged up from their graves,
Or then those mists felt by the souls of men,
When they descend toth' Acharusian fen.
It should not strive within me, or be loath
To leave my body might it blast you both. He feigns to die.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: So with thy death the embryon of my love
Takes perfect shape. Now like the Sestian maid
May I court Leander swimming in my arms▪
And with our pleasing motions mock the seas
That rose and fell to wanton with his thighs:
Now there's no Hellespont betwixt our loves:
I am not jealous: Agamemnon's dead,
And Clytaemnestra with Aegisthus plays:
Pleasure is free.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.l: Come there's no pleasure in you:
You're a lustful time spent murderous strumpet,
The prostitution of your known bordelloes,
Where every itching lecher ●ents his blood,
is not so loathsome.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: You speak not like a lover.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.l: No, for thou hast killed my love Amada:
And now thy husband's blood bids me beware
Of some new lust and third adulterer:
Such is your love to me.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: O stop those killing accents, be more mild
I do forgive what you did speak: and ask
But a kind thought for all my loving task.
These eyes have seen you smile: look gently on me,
And let me read some milder characters:

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.l: Hence with thy serpent twines.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: I am no Lamia nor no Lestrygon,
No high-prized Lais: that thou shouldst esteem
Repentance purchased at too dear a rate:
Kings shall not come to Corinth where thou mayst,
Not with a common Ephereian trull,
Purchase a minute's pleasure: but with me
(As fair but yet more chaste by far then she)
Spend years of sweet content.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.l: Siren mine ears are stopped I will not hear thee.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: O would I had a Siren's charming voice,
I'd use no incantations but to thy ears,
Or were my tongue like Orpheus golden lyre,
To which the winds were hushed and heard it play
It should be silent but to please thy ears,
Or like the dying swan, would I might sing
A funeral elegy to my parting soul,
So that the music might but please thy ears:
What should I say?

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.l: Be dumb and leave me.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: Not till thou love, or else of life bereave me. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: Ha,
Are ye gone: all clear, damnation cease ye,
Ay, a known practised politician,
And thus outreached: oh my shallow brains.
Fell I so high? would I had fallen from heaven:
So, like a Phaeton I had fired the world:
Or like a flash of lightning on your heads,
Consumed you for these tricks: I died in tims
Like a true coward, counterfeited death,
For fear to die indeed: well then for my life
I am beholding yet unto my wit:
But for my legs I know not how they stand,
Are my bones stiff still, not broken?
Ha?

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.l: I am at last freed of my lustful love,
My hope is yet despair will arm her hands
To her own death, and save my sword a labour:
If not, 'tis but the taking back of what I gave,
And send her once again into her grave.
Now for my Julia, she is the main of all,
Her will I cease and keep, until the fleet
Now under sail for Florence be arrived,
From the grand signior sent to make me strong,
And get command upon the straits: howsoe'er
'Twas promised Borgias to make strong his part,
Against the Dukes: she being had,
My title's firm for Florence, their claim's bad.
Eunuch.

sp.speaker: Ferr.
sp.l: Your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.l: See you this body?

sp.speaker: Ferr.
sp.l: I do.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.l: Convey it to his bed there let it lie,
The murder I'll transport upon the Dukes,
Or on some treason by their means contrived:
See it be done.

sp.speaker: Ferr.
sp.l: It shall.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.l: Now unto Julia, on her lies my state,
If she consents: why so: if not I know
Death and command makes women's hearts to bow.Exit

sp.speaker: Ferr.
sp.l: The death of slaves pursue thee. hah Borgias,
Protector: true true: clap clap ye furies,
Dance your black rounds, and with your iron whips,
Fetching eternal lashes as you skip
Strike a loud sounding music through the air,
And make the night Queen pale to hear your noise.
Be peaceful wronged ghost wheresoe'er thou beest,
Post to the blessed fields where souls take rest:
Drink Lethe freely for thou art revenged.
Come thou enclosure of a damned soul,
I'll be obedient bear to thy bed,
Then in my chamber laugh that thou art dead.
sp.stage: Ferrara takes up Borgias, Borgias draws out Ferrara's dagger and stabs him with it.
sp.l: What sudden pain assaults my yielding heart?

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: Ha ha, ha, you'll bear me to my bed,
Then in your chamber laugh that I am dead.

sp.speaker: Ferr.
sp.l: Livest thou damned villain?

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: I live, and laugh vild slave to see thy fall,
This is the enclosure of a damned soul,
Villain thou shalt not breathe another word.

sp.speaker: Ferr.
sp.l: Stay but a minute longer, know that I have
Thy promise and thy oath to be my guard,
Thy slave I murdered and assumed his shape,
I am Ferrara.

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: Ferrara, ha? true true, clap clap ye furies
Dance your black rounds, and with your iron whips,
Fetching eternal lashes as ye skip,
Strike a loud sounding music through the air
and make the night's Queen pale to hear your noise:
You have my oath and promise for your guard:
So wise men promise fools, but their reward
Like thine Ferrara is the loss of breath.

sp.speaker: Ferr.
sp.l: Justice I thee implore, revenge my death

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: Mulleasses thinks me dead, and in his plots
Goes on securely: I'll return his policies,
And upon him transport Ferrara's murder.
My wife he hath forsook: that sweetens danger
That I but live to see revenge on her.
My weak force built upon the Turkish fleet,
I see is ruined, and I but undermined:
No hope is left save in mine own command
And power with the state: whose light credulity,
I easily did delude with Julia's death.
But yet Timoclea lives, and may perhaps
Escape her false love's hate: which if she do,
This black night's horror falls like thunder on me:
She must not live till day: be ever dark.
Stand night upon the noonestead: and attend
My fate's security: if ever blackness pleased
Or deeds to which men may resemble thee,
Turn then thy sooty horse, and with their feet,
Beat at the rising morn: and force the sun,
Forbear his lustre till this black deed's done. Exit.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: Hell and ye furies wheresoever you be,
Show me your tortures, and present yourselves
Or let the burning monarch clad in flame,
Make an infernal echo to my name.
I know not what I say: Timoclea wronged,
Love-slighted and contemned: oh my wish!
That like the cross-eyed witch of Thessaly
My voice could through the rivets of the earth
Hollo and call revenge: or rather: what?
My dangerous ghost attired like Nemesis
About her middle for a virgin zone
Girt with a forked-toothed serpent, vent at my breast
That did exceed a stepdame in my lust.
Forbear yet gentle maid; thy father's soul
Kneels at the brazen throne of Radamanth
And craves that office: whither am I born?
Despair, thou art a false glass to the soul,
And in the conscience dazzled with thy guilt
Of many sins, dost vary forms of fear.
I not believe thy forced suggestions,
I am seduced by passion: death and terror.

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: Error,Within.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: False air thou liest I err not: my love's wrong
I'll tear out of my breast: forget those hopes
Made my hands bloody: I am clear unstained:

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: Stained:

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: Forbear thy thunder gentle, gentle voice,
Beat not my conscience torments 'gainst the walls,
To make the court ring with thy clamorous answers:
Heavens let my tears redeem me unto life.

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: Life.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: Of my terror: I desire not: speak of death.

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: Death.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: Of my daughter: how easy through the air
Our sins are hurried: thou canst tell of murder.

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: Murder.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: I of my husband: night thy coal-black wings
Though darker than the moons eclipsed brow
Are not fit canopies for sin.

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: Timoclea.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: Distraction of my soul, who breathes my name!

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: The airy breath of him that sometime lived
A tenant in the breast of Borgias,
By thee driven out the frame and house of life.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: By me

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: And now like one whom stern oppression throws
Naked out of all he did possess: being robbed and spoilt
Of the warm covert he inhabited,
I sigh my helpless wrongs▪ and in the air
Counting all hope I had, find all despair.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: Despair.

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: And empty longings for an end of pain,
Which I still wish and crave.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: But never gain.

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: Never.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: Forgive me.

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: Ask it of the heavens,
To whom my blood with ceaseless clamours calls
For justice and revenge.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: Justice in heaven is like my sin 'gainst thee
Cruel: and sooner may I with my knees
Eat through the centre: from these pearly eyes
Should there fall down more tears of penitence
Then the clouds drop to purchase a new spring
I could not be forgiven.

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: Death is the winter doomed unto thy soul
Disrobe it of that warm and wanton flesh,
The mouth of justice bids Timoclea die.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: Be thou then justice executioner
Revengeful spirit: in this flesh of mine
Carve thy revenge in characters of blood
blast me: or from the centres hollow deep
Let lose some conjured tempests: whose loud storms
Driven through the air sings horror to the world,
And let them hurl me 'gainst the labouring clouds
Sink to the brazen-gated deep abyss,
Where furies sit curling their snakes in knots,
And pull a viper from Allecto's head,
And on these breasts that in thy heat of life,
Have been as pillows to advance thy lust
Let it suck freely: the Egyptian Queen
Ne'er died more daring.
And to the stern commissioners of blood,
Be a glad Hermes: tell them, Timoclea
Takes vengeance on herself dull element be gone.

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: The morning's saffron horse breathes from the East
Their spicy vapours, sucked from th'indian plains
And through the gentle air hurl their perfumes.
I hear the sun's steeds trot towards the milky way,
And in a coach of flames draw up the day:
Aurorat usher to the stars of night,
Tells the approching of the god of light:
They 'gin to twinkle and take in their fires
At their eclipse we spirits leave the air,
And in a dismal vale of darkness groan,
Under the burden of a thousand chains:
I must away, thou only dost detain me,
With want of vengeance, which thy death must gain me.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: It shall, it shall:
Hard hap of misery, it hath many hands,
That like the windings of a labyrinth,
Leads the despairing wretch into a maze:
But not an Ariadne in the world,
That lends a clue to led us out the world.
The very maze of horror.
Cease thou that stands first mover of the spheres
from whose high concave all inferior fires
Derive successive motion.
Stand ye night-wandering planets in a maze,
And from your hollow fabrics view Timoclea,
Or else ye heavens put in your flaring lights,
And on your azure-seiled arches hang
A raven-black canopy of congealed clouds
That you may seem a chaos to the world,
And bode eternal darkness: thou wert not made to kill,
Nor was the diadem of her pontic Queen
Made as a fatal instrument of death,
And yet it was the engine stop her breath
As thou must mine. Soul of Borgias
Thus to thy ghost I sacrifice my life,
To buy thy requiem.

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: I accept it wife.
sp.stage: He strangles her with her own hair.
sp.l: And thus return the fall of Borgias.
Nay nay repent not dear Timoclea,
You're caught in faith: then like a lioness
Snared in the wary hunter's tangled toils,
Grind the thin air: swell higher till thou burst,
And let the breath that like a vapour pressed
Struggle within thy bosom, hurl thee up.
Soft — the time spends fast, and I have much to think of
Before the tell-tale god displays his light,
To show the world the horror of this night.
First for thy death the lustful Turk must die,
My rival in the love of Julia.
Him I'll accuse for murdering thee. The Dukes
Because his claim may alienate my hopes
Him in my accusation I will join
As joint coagent in the Turk devises.
As for that rumour of fair Julia's death,
I'll first proclaim her life: and on mulleasses
(Who now detains her) will transfer the falsehood,
As if myself had been by him deluded:
These mazes when like Theseus I have trodden
Fortune shall spread her wings to make me sails,
And with a strong air cut the angry tide,
That into mountains swells to stay my pride.
Hah! what heavy noise beats through my ears?
Hang heavy Morpheus on the eyes of men,
And make suspicion sleep.

sp.speaker: Philen.
sp.p: The rumours strange I pray possess me with your proper knowledge.

sp.speaker: Phego.
sp.p: You shall understand sir, that according to my function, giving near attendance to my lady, she being fervently employed in the lobby, about a mixture or composure of (As we vulgarly term it) a posset: upon our first entrance, ere we had relished the sweet of her sweet, that is the fruit of her labours, we were suddenly assailed by a she-goblin: to describe it sir I am not able, for my eyesight turned inward to look after my heart that was running from my heels, yet thanks to the lankness of my calf they made reasonable haste.

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: Heart of all mischief see the court is up,
Hell and the darkness keep me from their sight.

sp.speaker: Philen.
sp.l: At midnight did Ferrara leave his chamber,
Heavens be his safety.

sp.speaker: Phego.
sp.p: A ghost a ghost. Exit Borgias

sp.speaker: Philen.
sp.l: Pursue it where it goes: fear shall not stop me.
Follow me sir, I'll speak to it, though death
Cease on my life: it shall not lose mine eyes
Unless it sink into the earth. Exit.

sp.speaker: Phego.
sp.p: 'Sfoot my office is italianated, I am fain to come behind.

sp.speaker: Bord.
sp.p: Was ever man thus distracted between the flesh and the spirit? 'sfoot this pill hath so fired my mansion that unless I light on some waterwork, I shall lose the reins like a second Phaeton, and burn my fabric. Surely I am that Tantalus the hungry poet's talk of, and am as dry as an eel in a sandbag, and yet want water for the reaching: let me see, why should I fear spirits that have raised up such an able one at my pleasure, that like a bold orator stands on tiptoes to speak in bar: and yet methinks he should be no good pleader, he was so suddenly dejected and out of countenance with an apparition. I would the case were laid open, that I might see how my young mooter would bestir himself: ha: who is this? no more ghosts I hope: if it be it is the more womanly of the two. She lies as if she knew the end of her creation. On my life some waiting maid that hath a court epilepsy come upon her: I'll see if she foam at the mouth. Out and alas, the heavens have conspired poor bordelloes overthrow. The virtuous Timoclea wretched and most accursed hands, that have trussed up my fortunes in thy elf-knot.

div.head: Scaena 2.
div.stage: Enter Duke of Venice, lord Prusias attend.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: These apparitions do import more weight
Than our distracted judgements can yet poise,
Yet mighty Duke suspend a while all fear
If both my power in state and worth in honour
May be sufficient gage to be your guard
Then think you are in safety.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Sir we thank you: neither is there one
known unto us in Florence, on whose worth,
I dared assure such safety as from you,
And to that end I brought this gentleman,
As well to acquaint you with this deep occurrence,
That much concerns your present state, as crave
A guard for our security 'gainst danger.

sp.speaker: Prus.
sp.p: Respect your guard great Duke. Villain what art thou

sp.speaker: Bord.
sp.p: A most dejected parcel of man's flesh.

sp.speaker: Prus.
sp.l: Lend your eyes and see
A deed as black as is the time that hides it:
A murdered gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Ignoble villain, could thy coward-arm
Presume the least wrong to her feeble sex?

sp.speaker: Bord.
sp.p: Wrong: heavens know I meant to have done her as much right as could have been done to one of her sex.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Death hath not changed her form: see her face,
You may discern her by her character.

sp.speaker: Lord,
sp.l: She bears the image of Timoclea
Wife unto Borgias.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Soul of delusion, in this very shape
The ghost of Julia was presented unto me.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Amazement and the giddy thought of fear
Run an unsteady circuit through my brain:
Thy fear and trembling doth proclaim thy guilt.

sp.speaker: Bord.
sp.p: Alas sir my shaking proceeds of a standing ague I have had this two hours.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: The time importunates and craves sudden counsel.
Guard cease him safe, some bear this body hence,
We'll unto Borgias chamber, him we'll wake,
Acquaint him with the ground of our suspicion:
Mean time be safe in me: nor love nor life
Shall turn mine honour's current: I'll be your guard:
This hand seems your person, or my sword
Shall in the traitors heart make good my word. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena 3.

sp.speaker: Juli.
sp.l: If thou beest humane, then forsake thy suit
Your words are strange to me: my virgin ears
Ne'er knew such sound: desist I will not bow.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.l: We lose all pleasure that we do not know
Then like Pandora view those heavenly gifts.
The gods have decked thee with: see but thyself
And taste more pleasure from thy proper good
Then from the full horn of the Protean flood:
Elysium is in thee, and I implore —

sp.speaker: Juli.
sp.l: Syrens have left the sea and sing on shore.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.l: Could I outsing those Syrens Julia,
Or were my voice as tuneful as that harp
That now vies music with the harmonious orbs,
To which each learned sister nailed a star,
Thou mightst with safety hear me: thy uncle's love
Cold as the white head of the Apennine
Feels not my fire: ambition of rule
Turns all the heat is left in him to incest.
If thy warm blood (That dallies in thy veins,
And through thy flesh like wanton riuilets plays)
Desires with Nile to rise above her banks,
And vent in pleasure on the neighbouring plains;
A carpet richer than the breast of Tempe,
Or Tagus yellow channel, shall be spread
And pressed with Julia's weight.
Nor the blue sea-god when in storms he treads
On pearls as orient as the rysing East,
For which the toiling negro dives in vain,
Are boasted of such wealth: thy bed as soft
As down feathers plucked from Leda's swans,
Shall yield unto thy dalliance,
a hundred boys like winged cherubins
As fair as Psyche's love shall —

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.l: Enough, too much: I am not fit for pleasure
Or if I were thy mermaid eloquence
Sounds harsher in my ears then Silla's dogs
Unto the frighted seaman.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.l: Lady.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.l: Heathen profane.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.l: Be gentle madam.

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.l: If thou beest gentle leave me Mahomet
Our loves like our religions are at wars
And I disclaim all peace.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.l: And I a lover's smoothness: your uncle's dead
His power is mine, and you must go.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.l: Soul of wrongs: whither? you're both too weak
There's more than woman in me: villain, slave:

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.l: You urge me unto violence come to my chamber.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.l: In hell or in my grave: a rape, treason: treason.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: A guard, a guard.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.l: Death of my hope the court is up.

div.stage: Enter lord, Venice, and attendants: with Bordello bound.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: From hence the voice was heard, be circumspect.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.l: Treason, treason.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Who speaks that word?

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.l: Julia your sovereign.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.l: Silence or thou diest.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Error of darkness in what labyrinth
Our souls are plunged: raise the court: Julia?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Julia and mulleasses?

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.l: Julia and mulleasses fond venetian
Prevented at the point of happiness:

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Thus I redeem her.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.l: And like Cephalus kill thine own Procris.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Save me.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Thy death shall be her freedom infidel.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.l: Why stop you in your courses short breathed Christians?
Nail us together. Now methinks I stand
Like a proud lion with a richer prize
Than Nessus would have stolen from Hercules
And dare your envies: my death unto your state
Shall be as ominous as his poisoned shirt:
Your false protector's dead: he mocked your griefs
And made you weep at Julia's funeral,
Whose hope I underwrought, and now had worn
The wreath of Florence: love and ambition,
Kindled my cold brain from their mutual heat
Sprung my aspiring aim: nor shall it sink
But in the death of Julia: since I cannot
Quench my hot thirst of lust, and cool the heat
That hotter than the coals of parta
Burn in my liver: like the snowy dragon,
Tangling the elephant in his snarled orbs:
I'll die in the pursuit of my desire,
And mix our bloods in death to sate my fire,

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Hold monster.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Damnation on thy soul.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Thy death shall ransom her.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.l: Death double thy feared force, and it some form
Affright pale Hecate darken the moon,
I like the sun, backed on th'arcadian beast,
When in his burning progress he did sing
Adonis' gardens: from my soul's fair light
Chase cloudy fear: and like Thetis son,
When he was ointed with Ambrosia
Am more than fire-proof: lives Julia yet?

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: She lives damned villain and outlives thy hate.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.l: Death had been kind in her: with her I might
Under the cool shades of Elysium
Played before Pluto and made Proserpine
As jealous as Juno of my love —
But since I must not

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: Up from the dark earth's exhalations
thicker than Lerna's foggy mists and hide me:
I cannot lose their sight, hell of fear!

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: It flies our eager steps: follow, follow.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: What means these clamours: Borgias?

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.l: Ha, Borgias:

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: Horror of ●oules I am surprised.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.l: Illusive air, false shape of Borgias,
Could thy vain shadow work a fear in him
That like an Atlas underwent the earth
When with a firm and constant eye he saw
Hells fifty headed porter: thus I'd prove
Thy apparition idle: — runs at Borgias.

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: Treason: I live: devils and furies I am slain.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Wonder of admiration: what distraction is this?

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.l: Ha ha, ha: climb high my mounting spirit
And when thou hast aspired to thy full height
Like a colossus on a base of clouds
Stand and applaud thy fortunes: Borgias

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: Grinest hellish antic?

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.l: Should the Cecropian thief stretch my torn flesh
Racked on his bed of steel: if on Caucasus
My growing liver were exposed a prey
To ravening praetors: I would still laugh
To see thee like a falling pinetree reel
In a rough tempest.

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: Hold up ye broken organs of my soul
Carry me high and make me stand as firm
As oaks on Ossa: that advance their tops
Even till their roots break. Timoclea

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.l: For love of me killed her own child
Thy daughter Amada.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Amazement!

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: Blessed fates I thank you: I shall die revenged
Fly, Jove loved Nemesis and at justice feet
Shake thy triumphal ash: I slew Timoclea

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.l: By thee before thought dead
I took her from the hearse of Julia,
When in the habit of a murdered ghost,
This night she appeared to the Duke, to breed
Suspect in them of thee, and arm their hate
Unto my plotted faction.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Damned illusion.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Where is Ferrara?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Heavens be his guard.

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: So they are. He killed my slave
And in his habit by this hand he died.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: False perjured villain. He runs at him.

sp.speaker: Borg.
sp.l: Sink, sink Cithaeron, high Pallene tremble
Green Tempe wither, and with me forgo
Your place and being, this whole world of flesh
With fatal earthquakes totters.
False Turk thy fate be but as cruel as is Borgias hate. Moritur.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.l: Stoop down thou Lydian mount, bend thy cold head
And hide it in thy brackish father's waves
That as thou shrinkest, thy starry load may nod
At mulleasses fall: or ever shroud
Those joyful bonfires in a mourning cloud.Moritur.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Just end of treason.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Madame our duties joy your life
And wish your happiness.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: As the just reward of danger.
My lord I claim her love.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Not without justice brave Venetian
She is herself and free.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.l: And thus I give myself.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Heaven's seal it for the the good of both our states.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Philenzo:
We can but grieve at great Ferrara's loss:
Ambassadors from us shall plead our sorrows
Even to your senates: mean time his obsequies
Shall want no honour: signior bordello
We give you liberty: what remains undone
Shall by the senate be confirmed: lead on.

A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
